transcription.text: It started as an experiment, with Canadian filmmakers Graeme Ferguson, Roman Kroiter and Robert Kerr setting out to see if they could make a massive, multi-screen experience. Famously the group pulled off the complicated task of syncing nine film projectors to create a large screen installation. More than 50 years since it debuted at EXPO ‘67 in Montreal, IMAX has become synonymous with cinematic innovation. Championed by pioneering filmmakers like Christopher Nolan, James Cameron and J.J. Abrams, it has come a long way from its early reputation as the home of nature documentaries. With a combination of stadium seating, giant curved screens, immersive sound and 70mm film projection, its unique viewing experience has seen IMAX theatres established all over the world.

From bold colours and carefully composed frames to his trademark symmetry, Wes Anderson’s films are instantly recogniseable – and easily imitated. Social media users across the world have mimicked his techniques to put a whimsical lens on their cities. With over 326,000 likes and 1178 comments, this one stands out. By marrying Anderson’s playfulness with the seriousness of war, Ukrainian activist Valeria Shashenok uses social media and a smartphone to counter media narratives of a war-torn country and proves that creativity can’t be defeated.

work.title: If Wes Anderson made a movie in Ukraine

transcription.text: The fun-loving Humphrey B Bear first bounded onto Australian TV in 1965 and has been bringing joy to children and adults ever since. Humphrey was the star of the Here's Humphrey show, one of the world's longest-running kids' TV shows with around 3,000 episodes. Humphrey's popularity is evident in all this merchandise and memorabilia, which shows how Humphrey has inspired children across decades to play, learn and create at home.

Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.

Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, he goes from confused to defensive when he realises he actually thinks about Rome a lot, like many other men according to the virality of the trend. Though a light-hearted prank-style meme, it can also be interpreted as demonstrating the link between idolising ancient Western history and toxic masculinity. To find out how, collect this display on your Lens and read more online.

work.title: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?

transcription.text: All those videogame and anime-inspired avatars you’re seeing on social media aren’t as innocent as they look. After uploading selfies and paying a small fee, the Lensa app can turn users into fairy princesses and rugged adventurers. But the AI-generated artworks are trained on the work of actual artists, some of whom fear their creativity will be replaced by computers. Non-White users have also reported that the app anglicised their features, while at other times it’s created sexualised images from childhood pictures. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and giving up their personal data. So, look before you Lensa.

Reproduction movie lobby card set for the promotio of the film 'House of Wax' a Warner Brothers production c1953. The set contains a series of eight colour pinted cards with illustrated scenes from the movie and graphic text noting 'Natural Vision, Color by Warner Color, 3 Dimension, House of Wax.

In the original trailer for House of Wax (1953), Warner Brothers heralded the third dimension as “the new wonder of the entertainment world”. Though that wonder had been discovered a year earlier in Bwana Devil (1952), Warner Brothers explored immersion further by releasing a colour 3D feature that incorporated stereo sound for the first time. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.
Hand painted magic Lantern slide photo set with wooden frames with the 'History of John Gilpin' pictured

work.title: History of John Gilpin hand-painted lantern slides

transcription.text: Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm? More so, Klum's elaborate costumes also pay homage to the movie-making magic of prosthetics and make-up.
